raw_text:
House prices drop as sales slow
 
 House prices fell further in November and property sale times lengthened as rate rises took their toll, the Royal Institute of Chartered Surveyors found.
 
 A total of 48% of chartered surveyor estate agents reported lower prices in the three months to November - the highest level in 12 years. Meanwhile the number of sales dropped 32% to an average of 22 per surveyor. The amount of unsold properties on their books rose for the sixth month in a row to an average of 67 properties. "The slowdown occurring in the market has given buyers more power to negotiate, but this time of year is traditionally a quiet one," RICS housing spokesman Ian Perry said. "The decision by the Bank of England not to increase interest rates further and the healthy economy is allowing confidence to consolidate."
 
 The figures support recent data from the government and other bodies which all point to a slowdown in the housing market. On Monday, the Council of Mortgage Lenders, British Bankers Association and Building Societies Association all said mortgage lending was slowing. The figures were published as another survey by property website Rightmove said the average asking price of a home fell by more than £600 from £190,329 in November to £189,733 in December. Around the UK, the Midlands and South saw the biggest price falls, while London prices fell but at less than the national rate. In Scotland, where prices have remained on an upward path, increases were more "moderate", RICS added. But the news failed to dent confidence that sales will recover in future, with surveyors at their most optimistic in a year - as new purchase inquiries stabilised despite holding at lower levels. "Sales usually pick up in the New Year and I am confident this year will be no exception," Mr Perry added. Looking ahead, the group is anticipating a quiet start to 2005 with the market picking up in the second half - prompting a 3% rise in prices over the coming 12 months.
llama3.2:1b: House prices fell by 48% in November and sales dropped 32%.
This marks the highest level of price decline in 12 years.
The number of unsold properties increased to 67, averaging 22 per surveyor.
Sales figures have been historically low, but confidence is holding up due to a healthy economy and interest rate decisions.
llama3.2:3b: House prices fell by an average of £600 in November, with 48% of chartered surveyors reporting lower prices, and sales dropped 32%.
Unsold properties increased for the sixth month in a row to an average of 67.

The slowdown is due to rate rises taking their toll, but the Bank of England's decision not to increase interest rates further has allowed confidence to consolidate, with buyers having more power to negotiate.
gemma2:2b: House prices dropped in November, sales slowed significantly, and unsold properties increased.
This slowdown gives buyers more negotiating power.
Despite the slow down, confidence remains high for future market recovery.
RICS predicts slight price increases in the next year.

The RICS survey shows that fewer than half of estate agents reported lower house prices and the number of unsold homes on their books increased compared to previous years.
Prices are expected to fall again in 2005 with new sales picking up towards the end of the year.

Chartered surveyors reported lower prices (48%) and fewer sales (32%).
The number of unsold properties rose for the sixth month in a row to an average of 67 on their books.
This slowdown occurred during traditionally slow months, which is good news for buyers but could indicate market consolidation.
The Royal Institute of Chartered Surveyors expects that with confidence consolidating and interest rates not increasing further, sales will rebound starting in January.
qwen2.5:3b: House prices fell further in November due to slower sales and longer sale times as interest rates increased.
A quarter of estate agents reported lower prices, down 32% in sales compared to last year, with unsold properties rising for six consecutive months.
This market slowdown has given buyers more bargaining power, although it is traditionally quiet during this time.
Despite Bank of England decisions not to increase interest rates further and a healthy economy, mortgage lending remains slow.
Rightmove's survey showed house prices dropping by over £600 in December.
The Midlands and South experienced the largest price decreases.
London saw a smaller decrease compared to national rates.
RICS predicts moderate increases in Scotland.
Surveyors are optimistic about future sales recovery, though they anticipate a quiet start in 2005 with a gradual rise expected over the next year.

The figures support recent data from the government and other bodies which all point to a slowdown in the housing market.
On Monday, the Council of Mortgage Lenders, British Bankers Association and Building Societies Association all said mortgage lending was slowing.

However, confidence in mortgage lending and property sales is expected to recover in future, with surveyors at their most optimistic in a year.

Nearly half of surveyors reported lower prices, the highest level in 12 years, while sales dropped 32% and unsold properties increased for the sixth consecutive month.
The slowdown has given buyers more negotiating power, though the market is typically quieter at this time of year.
Despite declining mortgage lending and falling asking prices, surveyors remain optimistic about a recovery, expecting sales to pick up in the New Year and a 3% price rise over the next 12 months.
stablelm2:1.6b: House prices drop by 2% in November as sales slow due to rising interest rates and bank decisions not to increase rates further.
Royal Institute of Chartered Surveyors reports that 1 in every 5 estate agents reported lower prices, while the number of sales dropped 20% to an average of 1 sale per surveyor.
Unsold properties rose for the sixth month consecutively, with an average of 250 properties on estate agents' books.

Surveys by property websites show that house prices fell by around £10,0..
The Royal Institute of Chartered Surveyors found that house prices dropped further in November with the highest number of surveyors reporting lower prices in years.
Meanwhile, the number of sales dropped 20% to an average of one sale per surveyor.
Unsold properties on estate agents' books rose for the sixth month in a row to an average of 250 properties.
According to housing spokesman Ian Perry, the decision by the Bank of England not to increase interest rates further and the healthy economy allows confidence to consolidate.
The Royal Institute's data supports recent reports from government and other bodies indicating a slowdown in the housing market.
Property websites also showed that house prices fell by around £10,000 compared to the previous month.

In summary: House prices drop 2% in November due to rising interest rates and bank decisions not to increase them further; Royal Institute of Chartered Surveyors reports that half of estate agents reported lower prices; unsold properties on estate agents' books rose for the sixth consecutive month, with an average of 250 properties.
The housing market is slowing down, and confidence in recovery is high despite some quiet periods.
New purchase inquiries are stabilising at lower levels, with sales expected to recover by the end of this year.
The Royal Institute anticipates a relatively quiet start to 2019 followed by an increase in prices over the next few months.
granite3.1-dense:2b: House prices in the UK have experienced significant drops and slowdowns, according to the Royal Institute of Chartered Surveyors (RICS).
In November, 48% of chartered surveyor estate agents reported lower house prices, marking the highest rate in 12 years.
Property sales also decreased by 32%, averaging 22 per surveyor, and unsold properties increased to an average of 67.
This trend is attributed to post-rate rise market conditions.

Despite these negative indicators, RICS housing spokesman Ian Perry expressed cautious optimism for future sales recovery in the second half of 2005, predicting a 3% price increase over the next 12 months.
Other financial bodies reported similar slowdowns in mortgage lending.
The Midlands and South saw the most substantial price declines, while London's prices fell less than the national average.
In Scotland, where house prices have traditionally been on an upward trend, increases were more moderate.
